user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 flags)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t        arg;
    int32                           return_code;
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *     task;

    memset(&arg, 0, sizeof(arg));

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    arg.id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token);

    task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, *token);
    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    return_code = OS_Posix_InternalTaskCreate_Impl(&impl->id, task->priority, task->stack_size, OS_PthreadTaskEntry,
                                                   arg.opaque_arg);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in this function modifies either of the function parameters. Details: 
- The pointer parameter token is only read and dereferenced (*token) when used as an index/argument; there is no assignment to token, no increment/decrement, and no re‑binding of the pointer variable. Reading the object referred to by the pointer is permitted by the rule. 
- The scalar parameter flags is unused and is not assigned to or otherwise modified. 
- The assignment arg.id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token) calls a function with token as an argument but does not modify the token variable in this function; even if the callee modifies the object pointed to, that is allowed by the rule (the pointer itself must not be modified). 
- The calls to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...) and OS_Posix_InternalTaskCreate_Impl(...) use *token or impl->id but do not change the value of the parameter variables. 
Given the above, there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
